superconsumers_pulse_spotlight.title: 1 in 4 Australians are in the dark about the insurance in their super: Pulse Spotlight
superconsumers_pulse_spotlight.summary: Super Consumers Australia's Pulse survey reveals that many Australians are unaware of or misunderstand their default superannuation insurance.

key_findings.finding: 27% of respondents are unsure if they have insurance (19%) or don't know what their policies are (9%).
key_findings.sub_finding: Over half of 25-29 year olds don't know default insurance starts at age 25.

key_findings.finding: Australians paid $6.785 billion for group super insurance in 2023-24.
key_findings.sub_finding: Insurance policies are often default and not personalized.

key_findings.finding: Knowledge of super insurance varies by demographics:

details.detail: Those in self-chosen funds (79%) were more aware than those in default funds (71%).
45% don't know if they have insurance or what it is (typically no default insurance at this age).
84% (55-64) and 88% (65+) know about their insurance, compared to 73% overall.
31% of women vs 24% of men don't know what insurance they have.
Knowledge remains relatively low and consistent across this age range, despite significant life changes.

key_findings.finding: Half of those recently reaching the default insurance age (25) are unaware of it.
key_findings.sub_finding: 74% of 18-24 year olds either didn't know or answered incorrectly about automatic enrollment after age 25.

key_findings.finding: Cost of default insurance is significant:

details.example: Cbus example: a 40-year-old in a dangerous occupation pays $798 annually for life and TPD cover.

details.impact: Productivity Commission (2018): Group insurance caused 'excessive' super balance erosion, potentially reducing retirement income by $85,000 - $125,000.

superconsumers_pulse_spotlight.call_to_action: Super Consumers is calling for a Productivity Commission review of insurance in super to address:
review_focus_areas: Appropriateness and equity of providing insurance within super.
Net public benefits and costs associated with insurance in super.
Gaps and overlaps with other support schemes (workers' compensation, Centrelink, NDIS).
Policy changes to enhance the value of insurance in super (standardized terms, consistent default cover, consumer protections).

survey_details.name: Pulse 2024 survey
survey_details.representation: Representative of the Australian population based on age, gender, and location

superconsumers_retirement_targets_method.title: Update to Super Consumers Australia Retirement Savings Targets Methodology
superconsumers_retirement_targets_method.purpose: To determine how much superannuation is needed for retirement, providing spending targets for two cohorts (around 65 and 55 years old) at three spending levels (30th, 50th, and 70th percentile).

changes: Removed multigenerational households from the sample to improve accuracy of expenditure estimates for single and couple households.
Sampling real returns instead of nominal returns.
Sampling monthly returns instead of annual returns (eliminating overlapping periods).
Included historical Australian Bank Bill and Australian Bond returns in the calibrated long-run constructed portfolio real return mean.
Calibrated to a historical arithmetic average instead of a geometric average.

changes.change: Lowered productivity assumption from 1.5% to 1.2% to align with the 2023 Intergenerational Report, impacting real wage growth and Age Pension growth.
Adjusted the model to account for legislated indexing of the Age Pension, considering cost of living increases (LCI/CPI) and benchmarking to male total average weekly earnings (MTAWE).

model_details.portfolio: 60/40 growth/defensive investment portfolio held from age 65 to 90 (26 years)
model_details.portfolio_composition: 26.4% Australian Equities, 26.4% World Equities, 7.2% Australian Listed Property, 16% Australian Fixed Interest, 16% World Fixed Interest, 8% Cash
model_details.bootstrap_iterations: 10,000 paths of 26 years of annual returns

superconsumers_retirement_targets_method.acknowledgements: Research Advisory Council and the University of Melbourne Department of Finance

notes: ASFA's 'modest' standard covers basic living expenses.
ASFA's 'comfortable' standard includes leisure activities, a good standard of living, private health insurance, a car, household goods, and holidays.
A separate retirement standard exists for older retirees.

super_investment_earnings_tax.deductions: Tax deductions and credits are subtracted

under_60.tax: 17% (including Medicare levy) or marginal tax rate, whichever is lower

preservation_age_not_reached.tax: 22% (including Medicare levy) or marginal tax rate, whichever is lower

tax_factors: Tax-free and taxable components of the super
Withdrawal method (income stream or lump sum)

general_information.advice: Seek advice from the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) or a financial advisor
